docs.lead_paragraph: A simple urine test may be able to identify postmenopausal women who have an increased risk of heart disease, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in Circulation, the journal of the American Heart Association, scientists said early heart disease in these women appeared to be linked to high levels of the protein albumin in urine.

headline.main: Routine Analysis May Detect Heart Risk

docs.abstract: Simple urine test may be able to identify postmenopausal women who have an increased risk of heart disease (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a child is chronically ill, the whole family feels the pain, particularly the parents. Regardless of the disease, whether an emotional disorder or a physical disability, the stress suffered by families is remarkably similar. Mothers and fathers talk about guilt, anger and sheer exhaustion. Brothers and sisters can feel neglected. ''All of these children need a lot of extra work, and typically the mothers get the brunt of it, and sometimes they resent it,'' said Dr. Dennis C. Harper, professor of pediatrics and rehabilitation at the University of Iowa College of Medicine. Dr. Harper has been studying the impact of chronically ill children on families for 30 years.

headline.main: Love, Anger and Guilt: Coping With a Child's Chronic Illness

docs.abstract: Five women tell on how they cope with a child's chronic illness; discuss impact of illness on their own emotional well-being, on their marriages, and on their other children; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Children from families with a history of alcohol abuse show characteristics in their brains that may make them more susceptible to becoming problem drinkers themselves, a new study reports. Using magnetic resonance imaging, researchers from the University of Pittsburgh found potentially significant structural differences in the brains of teenagers from families with multigenerational drinking problems. The report was published in a recent issue of Biological Psychiatry.

headline.main: A Generational Link to Alcohol Abuse

docs.abstract: Study finds that children from families with history of alcohol abuse show characteristics in their brains that may make them more susceptible to becoming problem drinkers; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women's health and fitness magazines may not be the healthiest reading matter for teenage girls. Writing in the current issue of The American Journal of Health Education, researchers from Brigham Young University said there appeared to be an increased risk of eating disorders and other unhealthy weight-control practices among high school girls who were frequent readers of the magazines. Dr. Steven R. Thomsen, an associate professor of communications, was the lead author of the article, which was based on findings from surveys and tests of 498 girls at two Utah high schools.

headline.main: The Image Could Be the Wrong Message

docs.abstract: Researchers find what appears to be increased risk of eating disorders and other unhealthy weight-control practices among teen-age girls who are frequent readers of women's health and fitness magazines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing the risk of blindness caused by diabetes may be as simple as taking an aspirin every day, a study suggests. Researchers looking into retinopathy, the leading cause of blindness in the United States and a common complication of diabetes, say the condition appears to be caused in part by hundreds of microscopic blood clots that form in the eye.

headline.main: Aspirin May Save the Sight of Diabetics

docs.abstract: Researchers say that reducing risk of blindness caused by diabetes may be as simple as taking aspirin every day (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-tobacco groups, frustrated that warnings about cancer and heart disease do not always accomplish their goals, have been trying another tactic lately: advertisements that link smoking with impotence, complete with cigarettes that droop ominously when young women walk by. Although that contention has been disputed, a new study concludes that smoking and impotence do appear to be correlated.

headline.main: A New Warning for Male Smokers

docs.abstract: Anti-tobacco groups, frustrated that warnings about cancer and heart disease do not always accomplish their goals, launch advertisements that link smoking with impotence; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is now officially summer and peak grilling season has arrived. Although many questions have been raised in recent years about the safety of consuming foods cooked over hot coals, it would be hypocritical of me, the owner of three well-used grills, to suggest avoiding such fare entirely. Besides, what's a summer without barbecued chicken, grilled vegetables or, occasionally, barbecued ribs, burgers or sausages, especially now that low-fat burgers and sausages can be made with turkey or chicken, as well as beef and pork?

headline.main: Tips for the Season of Burgers and Briquettes

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on food safety during summer cookout season offers tips on reducing creation of carcinogens; recipes for several marinades (L)
